results.title: Gary
results.creator_credit: David Haythornthwaite, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
After a period of abrasive conflict Gary’s parents have separated. The effect of this is shown on the whole family, but Gary is so deeply affected, that his insecurities produce a stomach ulcer. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Haythornthwaite, Tom Manefield and Film Australia

results.title: Amy (A)
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
Amy is a 16 year-old aboriginal girl from the country now living in Sydney. She faces many problems at school, in getting a job, and in the community because of her colour. Photography by Dean Semler.

results.title: Choosing a leader
results.creator_credit: Julia Murphy, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “What Do You Think”.
An open-ended discussion film for teenaged groups dealing with the problem of choosing a leader. The story concerns a group of boys and girls hiking in the woods, facing the possibility of being lost. One boy, always highly admired because of his athletic prowess, wants to take one direction; another boy, with considerable logic on his side, wants to take the other. What are the factors the group must take into consideration in deciding whose leadership to choose? The question is left with the film audience.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Julia Murphy, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Being different
results.creator_credit: Julia Murphy, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “What Do You Think”.
Departing from the norm, from accepting patterns of dress or behaviour, can bring down on the head of an erring teenager the unqualified disapproval of his gang. Is this attitude valid? The film cites the case of a thirteen year old boy who has developed an interest in collecting butterflies - a hobby that his friends laugh at. Should he pursue his genuine interest, or should he conform?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Julia Murphy, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Having your say
results.creator_credit: Gudrun Parker, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “What Do You Think”.
Are there circumstances in which one group may justifiably deny to another a chance to have its say at a public meeting when a question concerning both is at issue? This problem comes to the fore in a clash between a teenage group and a community center committee. The young people are accused of destructive behavior and are, without a hearing, denied the use of the center. In retaliation they hire a hall to publicly voice their protest. The committee feels it too should be heard at the meeting. The question is left to the film audience.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gudrun Parker, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Honest truth
results.creator_credit: Gudrun Parker, Michael Spencer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “What Do You Think”.
This film poses the question of whether an honest judgment is better than diplomatic double-talk in situations where an individual’s feelings may be hurt. We listen in on the conversation of high-school teen-agers following a school play in which a popular but untalented student has the leading role. The editor of the school paper defends his right to print an objective critical review of her performance. Other students feel that she should be let down more gently. The audience is invited to take over discussion of the issue.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gudrun Parker, Michael Spencer and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Majority vote
results.creator_credit: Gudrun Parker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “What Do You Think”.
A film designed to provoke discussion on the question of whether the elected representative of a group may legitimately support a measure which is disliked by the majority of electors. A situation is presented in which a class of high-school students voice their disapproval of the support given by their student council representative to a measure curtailing their extracurricular activities. In defending her action the representative gives adequate reasons for her support of the measure. The audience is invited to express its opinions.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gudrun Parker and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: One man's opinion
results.creator_credit: Gudrun Parker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “What Do You Think”.
First in a series of discussion-provoking subjects, this film shows how one person’s judgment might reasonably run counter to the majority opinion. This is illustrated in a high-school classroom where a campaign is under way to raise funds for a school project. One student, although he believes in the cause, withholds his support because he disapproves of the high-pressure methods which put individuals on the spot if they are unable to or do not wish to contribute. The audience is asked for their appraisal.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gudrun Parker and National Film Board of Canada

group_siblings.title: Who's running things?

results.title: Who's running things?
results.creator_credit: Gudrun Parker, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “What Do You Think”.
The boys in a high-school gym class are penalized by their leader for breaking the rules. The film asks if, after a leader is elected, those who chose him can justifiably override his authority.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gudrun Parker, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
